column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#Text=[0061] FIGS. 9-10 illustrate this concept.
#Text=In this example, the filter module 110 has two bandpass wavelength filters.
#Text=Filter F1 is centered at 450 nm and filter F2 is centered at 650 nm.
#Text=FIG. 9A shows the subarray 133 when only filter F1 is used.
#Text=The corresponding image of a petal is shown in FIG. 10A.
#Text=Note that there are spots on the surface.
#Text=FIG. 9B shows the subarray 133 when only filter F2 is used.
#Text=The corresponding image of a petal is shown in FIG. 10B.
#Text=Note that there are rings on the petal surface.
#Text=FIG. 9C shows the subarray 133 when both filters F1 and F2 are used, but they are used in equal proportion.
#Text=That is, filter F1 occupies 50% of the pupil and filter F2 occupies the other 50%.
#Text=The resulting multimode image is shown in FIG. 10C.
#Text=Note that the rings at 650 nm are visible but the spots at 450 nm are not.
#Text=This is because the 450 nm component requires longer exposure or stronger illumination.
#Text=However, just increasing the exposure could overexpose the 650 nm component.
#Text=[0062] FIGS. 9D and 10D show a solution.
#Text=The filter module is positioned so that the 450 nm filter F2 occupies more of the pupil area, as shown in FIG. 9D.
#Text=The exposure condition is also adjusted so that components from both filters F1 and F2 receive the correct exposure.
#Text=In this example, the sum of the photons collected at all detectors behind each filter is optimized.
#Text=Care is taken to adjust the exposure/light power versus the filter area such that the detectors behind each filter is not saturated.
#Text=The resulting multimode image is shown in FIG. 10D.
#Text=Both the 450 nm spots and the 650 nm rings are visible.
#Text=[0063] FIG. 11 is a flow diagram of this solution.
#Text=The filter module begins at some initial position 1110.
#Text=For example, it may be positioned so that different filters cover the same pupil area.
#Text=With the filter module in this position, a multimode image is captured 1120 and processed 1130.
#Text=The processed image is used to calculate 1140 an image quality metric.
#Text=Examples of image quality metric include SNR, signal energy, contrast, brightness and exposure value.
#Text=If the quality is not sufficient 1150, then the position of the filter module and the exposure condition are adjusted 1160.
#Text=This is repeated until sufficient quality is obtained.
#Text=The resulting settings may be store 1170.
#Text=[0064] The multimode image can be processed 1130 in many ways, which may affect the image quality metric 1140.
#Text=For example, the processed image could be produced by summing or averaging all the detectors corresponding to each filter.
#Text=Alternately, several sub-images for one filter could be produced by demultiplexing the detectors behind a lenslet into one sub-image.
#Text=If the second method is chosen, then further processing might be applied to better define the image quality metric.

#Text=This additional processing could be averaging all the sub-images for a given filter, or choosing features that are best in each sub-image to define a "sharpest feature" image, a "highest SNR" image, etc.
#Text=[0065] The following is another example method for determining the exposure condition corresponding to the position for the filter module.
#Text=Let Q be the image quality metric.
#Text=Assume there are K filters f.sub.k.
#Text=In this example, there is an initial calibration (steps 1 and 2) before taking a sequence of images.
